I've recently been made aware thru this web site, that the drug might be responsible for an itchy skin allergic reaction that I've had since about the same time I began taking Primidone, though I cannot be certain as yet if the two are connected.  I've been on this drug for 5 months and up to now 4 tablets a day.  As yet, the drug has not stopped my hand tremors.  For me, and tremors are most embarrassing at social events.  I'm seeing my doctor next week to discuss with him the possibilities of trying something different.

column2: cdp, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Had trouble building a tolerance; took much longer to work up to a higher dose than my doctor had prescribed. I also had hallucination-type dreams and sleep disturbances at first, but stuck with it because I noticed an improvement in my voice tremors. Most of those unpleasant side effects have disappeared. Still, I can't tolerate the 250mg/day my doctor wants; have to settle with 150. Some days/times feel more tired. I think each individual will have to experiment to find the right balance.

column9: I have had epilepsy since age 13.  I started taking phenobarbitol with Dilantin and then at age 19 switched to Mysoline and Diamox.  When I was 25 I switched back to Mysoline and Dilantin.  I am on 360 mg. of Dilantin. All has been great other than now I have had to switch to generic Mysoline and I have had some side effects of drowsiness and fatigue.  I pray that these symptoms will soon go away like they did when I was 19.  This drug has been a life saver for me.  I am now a retired teacher and coach and have led a very productive and busy life.  I take 750 mg. per day.  I am still on the same dose but and was concerned about the generic Primidone.  So far - so good. It is a drug that you have to have patience with.  Anyone with experience of shifting from the real thing to generic?  Thanks, Lorie

column2: klockemy, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with benign hand tremors by my neurologist.  I was prescribed Primidone 50mg.  This stuff is great, no more hand tremors and a return of strength to the effected hand.  I was a little drowsy the first week of taking it, but when taken at bedtime, it can actually help you sleep.  Now, I don't get the sleepy side effects, but my hand is tremor free.  Even if I miss a dose, my hand immediatly doesn't go back to shaking nor to I get a withdrawal response.
